title: bootstrap: Don't use panics to report user errors

labels.name: E-help-wanted
labels.description: Call for participation: Help is requested to fix this issue.

labels.name: T-bootstrap
labels.description: Relevant to the bootstrap subteam: Rust's build system (x.py and src/bootstrap)

labels.name: A-contributor-roadblock
labels.description: Area: Makes things more difficult for new contributors to rust itself

body:
Currently, bootstrap uses `assert!` interchangeably between "we expect this command to always succeed" and "you, the user, did something wrong and need to fix it". See https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/d28ef9dbf1e9bedd0a30ad96ead65d95aaa09ebb/src/bootstrap/test.rs#L553 for an example of the former and https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/d28ef9dbf1e9bedd0a30ad96ead65d95aaa09ebb/src/bootstrap/test.rs#L1611 for an example of the latter. We should have more helpful error reporting for the latter, to make it more clear that it's not a bug.

The background motivation is that people are used to seeing the latter panics, and so don't report bugs when they see the former. This makes it hard to fix bugs because we don't know things are broken.
